question: Time series that tend to grow by a constant amount from period to period should be modeled by which trend model?
options: A) Linear trend model
B) Log-linear trend model
C) AR(1) model
D) MA(q) model
justification: Time series that tend to grow by a constant amount from period to period should be modeled by linear trend models.

question: Which statistic is used to determine if a trend model exhibits serial correlation?
options: A) R-squared
B) Durbin-Watson statistic
C) ACF plot
D) PACF plot
justification: The Durbin-Watson statistic is used to determine if a trend model exhibits serial correlation.

question: What is the autoregressive model of order p denoted as?
options: A) AR(p)
B) ARCH(q)
C) MA(q)
D) ARMA(p,q)
justification: The autoregressive model of order p is denoted as AR(p).

question: What conditions need to be satisfied for a time series to be covariance stationary?
options: A) Constant and finite expected value
B) Constant and finite variance
C) Constant and finite covariance with itself for a fixed number of periods
D) All of the above
justification: A time series is considered covariance stationary if it satisfies all three conditions: constant and finite expected value, constant and finite variance, and constant and finite covariance with itself for a fixed number of periods.

question: In which type of time series plot can an upward or downward trend be observed?
options: A) Stationary time-series plot
B) Covariance stationary time-series plot
C) Nonstationary time-series plot
D) Autoregressive time-series plot
justification: An upward or downward trend can be observed in a nonstationary time-series plot.

question: In a linear regression model, when is it valid to estimate an autoregressive time-series model?
options: A) When the time series is nonstationary
B) When the time series is covariance stationary
C) When the time series exhibits unit roots
D) When the time series has a unit root
justification: It is valid to estimate an autoregressive time-series model using linear regression when the time series is covariance stationary.

question: What are in-sample forecasts in time-series models?
options: A) Forecasts made for a time period different from the one used to estimate the model
B) Forecasts made for the same time period used to estimate the model
C) Forecasts made using out-of-sample data
D) Forecasts made using moving-average models
justification: In-sample forecasts in time-series models are forecasts made for the same time period used to estimate the model.

question: What criterion is used to compare the forecast accuracy of different time-series models?
options: A) R-squared
B) Standard deviation
C) Root mean squared error (RMSE)
D) F-statistic
justification: The root mean squared error (RMSE) is used as a criterion to compare the forecast accuracy of different time-series models.

question: Why are out-of-sample forecasts usually more valuable in evaluating the forecasting performance of a time-series model?
options: A) They provide forecasts for the same time period used to estimate the model
B) They provide forecasts for a time period different from the one used to estimate the model
C) They are based on moving-average models
D) They have a smaller RMSE
justification: Out-of-sample forecasts are usually more valuable in evaluating the forecasting performance of a time-series model because they provide forecasts for a time period different from the one used to estimate the model.

question: What is the term used to describe the phenomenon where coefficients in time-series models are often unstable across different sample periods?
options: A) Serial correlation
B) Covariance stationarity
C) Mean reversion
D) Coefficient instability
justification: The phenomenon where coefficients in time-series models are often unstable across different sample periods is referred to as coefficient instability.

question: When is a time series considered mean reverting?
options: A) When its level is above its long-run mean
B) When its level is below its long-run mean
C) When it tends to fall
D) All of the above
justification: A time series is considered mean reverting when it tends to fall when its level is above its long-run mean and rise when its level is below its long-run mean.

question: What is the order q of a moving-average model (MA(q)) determined by?
options: A) Nonzero autocorrelations of the time series
B) Zero autocorrelations of the time series
C) Partial autocorrelations of the time series
D) Serial correlation of the error term
justification: The order q of a moving-average model (MA(q)) is determined by zero autocorrelations of the time series.

question: What distinguishes autoregressive (AR) time series from moving-average (MA) time series in terms of autocorrelations?
options: A) time series in terms of autocorrelations?
A) Autocorrelations of AR time series start large and decline gradually
B) Autocorrelations of MA time series start large and decline gradually
C) Autocorrelations of AR time series suddenly drop to 0 after the first q autocorrelations
D) Autocorrelations of MA time series suddenly drop to 0 after the first q autocorrelations
justification: Autocorrelations of AR time series suddenly drop to 0 after the first q autocorrelations, whereas autocorrelations of MA time series start large and decline gradually.

question: What does significant serial correlation at seasonal lags indicate in a time-series model?
options: A) Seasonality
B) Volatility clustering
C) ARCH(1) errors
D) Trend component
justification: Significant serial correlation at seasonal lags indicates seasonality in a time-series model.

question: How can seasonality be modeled in a time-series model?
options: A) By including a seasonal lag in the model
B) By estimating a moving-average model
C) By using autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH) models
D) By adding an intercept term
justification: Seasonality can be modeled in a time-series model by including a seasonal lag in the model.

question: What limitations do ARMA models have?
options: A) Parameters can be very unstable
B) Determining the AR and MA order is difficult
C) They may not forecast well
D) All of the above
justification: ARMA models have several limitations including unstable parameters, difficulties in determining the AR and MA order, and potential poor forecasting performance.

question: What does autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH) represent in a time-series model?
options: A) Serial correlation
B) Mean reversion
C) Volatility clustering
D) Unit roots

question: What test can be used to determine if a time series has autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH)?
options: A) Durbin-Watson test
B) Dickey-Fuller test
C) Engle-Granger test
D) Ljung-Box test
justification: The Engle-Granger test can be used to determine if a time series has autoregressive conditional heteroskedasticity (ARCH).

question: In linear regression, when is it valid to use the method for modeling the relationship between two time series?

question: How can a time series with a unit root be transformed to be analyzed with an autoregressive model?

C) By first-differencing the time series

justification: A time series with a unit root can be transformed for analysis with an autoregressive model by first-differencing the time series.
